Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: An Integrated, Metabolomics-based Method for Metabolic Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Understanding and controlling cellular metabolism is crucial to applications ranging from industrial biosynthesis to bioenergy production, but is significantly hindered by limited information about the dynamics and regulation of metabolism. This CAREER project aims to use a computationally-driven approach to engineering cells to produce valuable chemicals, to be derived from cell-wide measurements of metabolite levels within the cell. To achieve this, a new metabolic model that includes regulation will be developed and used in an iterative experimental/computational manner for optimizing production of the valuable chemical succinic acid in the yeasts Saccharomyces cerevisiae and S. mikatae. This work will be the first of its kind to directly use cell-wide measurements of metabolites to drive metabolic engineering. Its successful completion will support the refocusing on rational design in metabolic engineering, and also increase the scope of chemicals that could be produced biosynthetically.

Broader Impact
This project has the potential to enable more efficient and effective engineering of metabolism, with applications ranging from the low-cost production of useful chemicals that become affordable to developing countries, impacting the quality of life for millions of people, to the facilitation of economically feasible production of biofuels for sustainable energy. Additionally, models that will be constructed for multiple species could help elucidate mechanisms of metabolic evolution. The integrated research and education plan of this project seeks to foster quantitative, whole system-level thinking in children, and to encourage the participation of underrepresented groups in engineering. To do so, existing educational programs that promote this mindset will be implemented in local socioeconomically-disadvantaged and predominantly minority schools. Also, a synthetic biology team will be assembled at a local high school to stimulate interest in systems biology, synthetic biology, and bioengineering, with targeted recruitment of females (underrepresented in engineering).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to support the principal investigator's career development, specifically in the context of modeling and engineering biological systems. As a result of this award, the principal investigator's team developed a new method for modeling large networks of chemical reactions in cells in a time-varying fashion, complementing the widely used modeling approaches that seek to model systems for a "steady state" where the system does not change. By tracking the time-varying levels of individual chemicals in the cells (rather than just how quickly the reactions are occurring) and combining this with information about which chemicals regulate which other reactions in the cell, a new framework was developed that could ultimately aid in the engineering of microbes for production of valuable chemicals.

In addition, multiple complementary areas of research also blossomed from the support provided by this award. Students whose involvement supported our outreach efforts and who received financial support from this award helped to forge a new line of inquiry in our research group, creating sensors made out of bacterial cells to apply to the detection of nutritional deficiencies in the developing world. Ultimately this developed into another line of inquiry supported in part by this award, where those sensors were instead made from extracts of those cells rather than the entire cells themselves. Moreover, we also developed multiple tools to aid in the processing and manipulation of large-scale biochemical data. We addressed the problem of "smoothing" out data with significant amounts of noise in it, and we addressed the problem where individual measurements are just missing from a large, complex dataset. The tools we developed to handle these situations were notable improvements over the state-of-the-art in these areas. Our chemical analyses of biological systems, which were done initially in support of our computational modeling work, also extended into the sensor systems described above, identifying new trends in these systems and suggesting ways to improve their performance.

Our work had a substantial broader impact beyond the publications and tools developed in this project. First of all, these efforts served as a training ground for the professional development of some of the next generation of biochemical scientists during their graduate school work, some of whom are now in their own independent professional careers. Moreover, we also made a concerted effort to support the training and scientific research exposure of undergraduate students, with an emphasis on groups that are underrepresented in engineering. In particular, we supported a significant number of female summer researchers, who are underrepresented not only in engineering, but even more so in computational sciences. We also made efforts to broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities through our support of undergraduate researchers. Finally, we had extensive involvement and outreach with a local high school, enabling the formation of a synthetic biology club and team that is consistently oversubscribed at their school and recently won numerous awards at an international science competition. This team in turn also conducted multiple societal outreach programs in which the principal investigator's research group participated.

Taken together, the intellectual/scientific contributions in the initially proposed field of research, the seeding of additional lines of inquiry in other related fields, the training of students in multiple age groups, the support for broadening participation of underrepresented groups, and the efforts for outreach to broader society outside of academia represent a substantial set of positive outcomes from the support provided by this award.
